translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)
The Chapter of the Sixes
The Birth Story of Avāriya
“Do not be angry, lord of the earth,

analyzed: māsu kujjha rathesabha  kuddham a paṭikujjhantaḥ
translated: do not be angry, chariot warrior.🔽The king is honored by the country
when he does not retaliate against the angry.
Whether in the village or the forest,
whether in the lowlands or the highlands;
Everywhere I advise you,
do not be angry, chariot warrior.”
“The father of Avāriya,
was a ferryman on the Ganges.
After previously ferrying people across,
he later asked for his wages;
Therefore he had a dispute,
and did not increase his wealth.”
“You should ask for the fare
before crossing to the other shore, dear ferryman.
For the mind of one who has crossed
is different from one who is crossing.
Whether in the village or the forest,
whether in the lowlands or the highlands;
Everywhere I advise you,
do not be angry, ferryman.”
“By the very advice
the king gave the best village,
by that very advice

original: nāviko paharī mukhaṁ.🔽Bhattaṁ bhinnaṁ hatā bhariyā,🔽Gabbho ca patito chamā;
analyzed: nāviko paharī mukha  bhattam bhinnam hatā bhariyā  gabbho ca patitaḥ chamā
translated: the ferryman struck him in the face.🔽The food was spoiled, the wife was killed,🔽and the fetus fell out of the womb;
like a deer with gold,
He is not a man to be thwarted in his purpose.”
The Jātaka of the Unrestrained One is the first.
